page.title: 14DOGMERSFIELD HOUSE:GARDEN
page.content: A survey of Dogmersfield Manor in the Domesday Book notes a church and a mill, the whole Manor valued at 100s and in the gift of Edward the Confessor. Henry II allowed part of his Royal Park at Odiham to be enclosed by his Bishop and the Dogmersfield estate grew to 2000 acres. In 1985,the portion belonging to the house consists of 27 acres. The grounds surround the Manor and contain many fine mature trees. There is also a walled herb garden,an orchard,tennis courts and a pair of brick dovecotes: one ancient, one rebuilt. The Park contains a small private cemetery where the remains of 6 brothers of the De La Salle order were buried between 1958 and 1968. Adjacent lie 3 other graves. The gardens are being restored by the new owners, Amdahl International.
